t: One man bears no compassion toward another, yet he entreats pardon for his own sins!
If he, being but flesh, cherisheth wrath, who shall make atonement for his sins?
Remember thy end, and let enmity cease; remember corruption and death, and abide in the commandments.
Remember the commandments, and bear no malice toward thy neighbor; remember the covenant of the Most High, and overlook ignorance.
Refrain from strife, and thou shalt lessen sins; for a wrathful man kindleth strife,
a sinful man disturbeth friends, and soweth discord among them that are at peace.
According to the fuel the fire burneth, and according to the stubbornness of strife it burneth; according to a man's strength is his wrath, and according to his wealth he increaseth anger.
A hasty contention kindleth a fire, and a hasty quarrel sheddeth blood.
If thou blowest upon a spark, it shall burn; if thou spit upon it, it shall be quenched; and both these come out of thy mouth.
Curse the whisperer and double-tongued, for he hath destroyed many that were at peace.
A third person's tongue hath disquieted many, and scattered them from nation to nation; it hath destroyed strong cities, and overthrown the houses of great men.
A third person's tongue hath cast out valiant women, and deprived them of their labors.
Whoso hearkeneth unto it shall not find rest, neither shall he dwell quietly.
The stroke of a whip maketh marks, but the stroke of a tongue breaketh bones.
Many have fallen by the edge of the sword, but not so many as have fallen because of the tongue.
Well is he that is sheltered from it, and hath not passed through the venom thereof; who hath not drawn its yoke, and hath not been bound with its bands.
For the yoke thereof is a yoke of iron, and the bands thereof are bands of brass.
A bitter death is the death it bringeth, and Sheol is preferable unto it.
It hath no dominion over the godly; they shall not be burned in its flame.
Such as forsake the Lord shall fall thereby; it shall burn among them, and shall not be quenched; it shall be sent forth upon them as a lion, and as a leopard it shall destroy them.
Look about thee and hedge thy possession about with thorns; bind up thy silver and thy gold.
Make a balance and a weight for thy words; and make a door and a bar for thy mouth.
Beware lest thou err therewith, and fall before him that lieth in wait.
Have mercy on thy neighbor when he is in need, and in like manner repay thy neighbor again in due season.
Confirm thy word, and keep covenant with him, and at all times thou shalt find that which is needful for thee.
Many, when a thing was lent unto them, reckoned it to be found, and put them that helped them to trouble.

Till he hath received, he will kiss a man's hand; and for his neighbor's money he will speak submissively; but when he should repay, he will prolong the time, and return words of heaviness, and complain of the time.

If he prevail, he shall hardly receive the half; and he will count it as a thing found; else he hath defrauded him of his money, and he hath gotten him an enemy without cause; he payeth him with cursings and railings; and for honor he will repay him with disgrace.
Many therefore have refused to lend, for fear of being defrauded without cause.
Howbeit show forbearance unto one in humble estate, and delay not to give unto him.
Help the poor for the commandment's sake, and turn him not away because of his poverty.
Lose thy money for thy brother and thy friend, and let it not rust under a stone to be lost.
Bestow thy treasure according to the commandments of the Most High, and it shall profit thee more than gold.
Shut up alms in thy store-chambers; and it shall deliver thee out of all affliction.
It shall fight for thee against thine enemy better than a mighty shield and a heavy spear.
A good man will be surety for his neighbor; but he that is lost to shame will fail him.
Forget not the good service of thy surety; for he hath given his life for thee.
A sinner will overthrow the good estate of his surety;
and he that is of an unthankful mind will forsake him that delivered him.
Suretiship hath undone many that were prospering, and shaken them as a wave of the sea; it hath driven mighty men from their homes, and they wandered among strange nations.
A wicked man transgressing the commandments of the Lord shall fall into suretiship; and he that undertaketh and followeth after gain shall fall into a suit.
Help thy neighbor according to thy power, and take heed to thyself that thou fall not.
The chief thing for life is water, and bread, and clothing, and a house to cover shame.
Better is the life of a poor man under a shelter of planks, than delicate fare in another man's house.
Be content, be it little or much, and thou shalt not hear the reproach of thy sojourning.
It is a miserable life to go from house to house; for where thou sojourneth, thou shalt not dare to open thy mouth.
Thou shalt entertain, and give to drink, and have no thanks; and besides this thou shalt hear bitter words;
'Come hither, sojourner, furnish the table, and if thou hast aught in thy hand, feed me therewith.'
'Get thee hence, sojourner, from the presence of them that are honorable; my brother is come as a guest; I have need of mine house.'
Grievous to a man of understanding is the reproach of sojourning; it maketh him feel like a debtor.
He that loveth his son causeth him to feel the rod, that he may have joy of him in the end.
He that traineth up his son shall have joy of him, and shall glory of him among his acquaintances.
He that teacheth his son maketh his enemy jealous, and before friends he rejoiceth of him.
Though his father die, yet he is as though he were not dead; for he hath left one behind him that is like himself.
While he lived, he saw, and rejoiced in him; and when he died, he was not grieved.
He left behind him an avenger against his enemies, and one that shall requite kindness to his friends.
He that spoilth his son shall bind up his wounds; and at every cry his bowels were troubled.
An horse unbroken becometh stubborn; and a child left to himself causeth sorrow.
Cocker thy child, and he shall make thee afraid; play with him, and he will grieve thee.
Laugh not with him, lest thou have sorrow with him, and lest thou gnash thy teeth at the last.
Give him no liberty in his youth, and wink not at his follies.
Bow down his neck while he is young, and beat him on the sides while he is a child, lest he wax stubborn, and be disobedient unto thee, and so bring sorrow to thine heart.
Train thy son, and make him diligent, lest thou be put to shame through his lewd behavior.
Better is a poor man being sound and strong of constitution, than a rich man that is plagued in his body.
Health and a good constitution are better than all gold; and a sound body than boundless riches.
There is no riches above a sound body, and no joy above the joy of the heart.
Death is better than a bitter life, and eternal rest than continual sickness.
Good things poured out upon a mouth that is closed are as messes of meat laid upon a grave.
What profit doeth an offering unto an idol? For neither can it eat nor smell; so is he that is persecuted of the Lord.
He beholdeth with his eyes and groaneth, as an eunuch that embraceth a virgin and groaneth.
Give not over thy soul to sorrow, and afflict not thyself in thine own counsel.
Gladness of heart is the life of a man, and the joyfulness of a man prolongeth his days.
Love thine own soul, and comfort thy heart; and remove sorrow far from thee; for sorrow hath destroyed many, and there is no profit therein.
Envy and wrath shorten the days; and care bringeth old age before the time.
A cheerful heart doeth good like a medicine; but a broken spirit drieth the bones.
The wakeful attendance of riches consumeth the flesh, and the care thereof driveth away sleep.
The rich man in his heap hath great labor; and he that seeketh after more is filled with care.
The poor man laboreth in his cottage; and if he cease from his labor, he is but needy.
He that loveth gold shall not be justified; and he that followeth after gain shall be filled therewith.
He that loveth gold shall hardly be justified, and he that followeth corruption shall have enough thereof.
Many have been brought to ruin for gold's sake, and their destruction was but a fitting end.
It is a stumbling block unto them that sacrifice unto it, and every fool shall be taken therewith.
Blessed is the rich that is found without blemish, and hath not gone after gold.
Who is he? Let us give praise unto him; for he hath wrought wonders among his people.
Who hath been tried thereby, and found perfect? Then let him glory. Who could have transgressed, and hath not transgressed? or done evil, and hath not done it?
Therefore shall his goods be established, and the congregation shall declare his alms.
When thou sittest at a bountiful table, be not greedy upon it, and say not, There is much meat on it.
Remember that a wicked eye is an evil thing: and what is created more wicked than an eye? therefore it weepeth upon every occasion.
Stretch not out thine hand whithersoever it looketh, and thrust it not with him into the dish.
Judge thy neighbour by thyself: and be discreet in every point.
Eat as it becometh a man, that is set before thee; and devour not, lest thou be hated.
Leave off first for manners' sake; and be not unsatiable, lest thou offend.
When thou sittest among many, reach not thy hand out first of all.
A very little is sufficient for a man well nurtured, and he doth not fetch his wind short upon his bed.
Sound sleep cometh of moderate eating: he riseth early, and his wits are with him: but the pain of watching, and choler, and pangs of the belly, are with an unsatiable man.
And if thou hast been forced to eat much, arise, go forth, vomit, and thou shalt have rest.
My son, hear me, and despise me not, and at the last thou shalt find as I have said: in all thy works be quick, so shall there no sickness come unto thee.
Whoso is liberal of his meat, men shall speak good of him: and the report of his good housekeeping will be believed.
But against him that is a niggard of his meat the whole city shall murmur; and the testimonies of his niggardness shall not be doubted of.
